pullRequest.body:
Give versions with weaker conditions for `intervalIntegrable.integral_deriv_mul_eq_sub`, `intervalIntegrable.integral_mul_deriv_eq_deriv_mul` and `fourierCoeffOn_of_hasDerivAt`.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:

- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

nodes.body:
Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8672925155/job/23783733892)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8672925155/job/23783733799)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8672925155/job/23783733755)
What about also adding a version assuming `HasDerivAt u (u' x) x` (still for all `x \in Ioo`)? I believe this would be the most common application, so probably worth having a dedicated lemma.

I think in many common applications you just have C^1 functions everywhere. Unless you want to prove a new lemma for an as general class as functions again (e.g. `fourierCoeffOn_of_hasDerivWithinAt`), and then you may want to generalize even further to this version. And your version is only one `.hasDerivWithinAt` away. Though granted, you sometimes have to write it as `(fun x hx => (h x hx).hasDerivWithinAt)` which is a bit cumbersome.
If you still think your version is worthwhile, I'll add it.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: generalize integration by parts
